item.title: Thoughts on Interviewing: II
item.description: In the first part of this series, I talked a little about how our industry interviews currently and some of the issues I have with the current process. In this post, I want to talk a little more about what we should be doing in interviews, and who we’re actually trying to hire.

item.title: Thoughts on Interviewing: I
item.description: As a developer for over 30 years, I’ve come to realize several problems with the way we interview in the Software Development industry. Whether it’s because we don’t know how to correctly interview for a development position, or we’re not allowed to interview in the way that’s needed, it needs to change.

item.title: On Software as Craft
item.description:
As A Craft  

As a self-proclaimed “Software Crafter”, I view the creation of software as an intricate art form, rather than a routine task akin to plumbing or factory work. This is not to belittle these professions, which are labor-intensive and require mastery of complicated processes, but to highlight the unique complexity inherent in software development.

item.title: Collaborative Programming... Remotely!
item.description: One of the most active topics at meet-ups and in online discussion groups in the last few months centers around “what works” and “what doesn’t work” when collaborative programming in our new era of all remote work. Over time, the one list of “do’s” and “don’ts” that has made it’s way to the forefront of discussions is the list at remotemobprogramming.org  , compiled by Simon Harrer, Jochen Christ, and Martin Huber.
